review.title: Event Structure of Transitive Verb: A MARVS perspective
review.abstract: Module-Attribute Representation of Verbal Semantics (MARVS) is a theory of the representation of verbal semantics that is based on Mandarin Chinese data (Huang et al. 2000). In the MARVS theory, there are two different types of modules: Event Structure Modules and Role Modules. There are also two sets of attributes: Event-Internal Attributes and Role-Internal Attributes, which are linked to the Event Structure Module and the Role Module, respectively. In this study, we focus on four transitive verbs as chi1(eat), wan2(play), huan4(change) and shao1(burn) and explore their event structures by the MARVS theory.

sections.text: In MARVS theory there are two different types of modules: event structure modules and role modules. In addition, there are two types of attributes: event internal attributes and role internal attributes associated with the event structure module and role module. In this study, we focus on four transitive verbs such as chi1 "eat," wan2 "play," "huan4" change "and shao1" burn "and examine their event structures using MARVS theory. Keyword: MARVS, event structure, event structure modules, intransitive verb

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In this sense, four verbs - chi1 "eat," wan2 "play," huan4 "change" and shao1 "burn" - were chosen as target words to predict their senses. There are two main reasons why these four target words were chosen: (1) they are all transitive verbs; and (2) they each have more than two senses. These two reasons may not fully explain why they were chosen from the many transitive verbs available in the corpus. To clarify our reasoning in selecting these four target words, we will use the module attribute representation of the verbal semantics theory (Huang et al 2000). Before explaining in detail why these four target verbs were chosen, we will present the module attribute representation of the verbal semantics theory (MARVS theory). Finally, we would like to examine the four transitive verbs as chi1 "eat," wan2 "play," "huan4" and their combustion theory "VS."
